newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: EU FALLS SHORT ON FOREIGN, DEFENCE POLICY.
newsitem.headline: EU FALLS SHORT ON FOREIGN, DEFENCE POLICY.

text.p: In a move that could have lasting consequences in world affairs, the European Union failed on Tuesday to take major steps towards building a common foreign and defence policy.

The 15 leaders, drafting a new Union treaty for the 21st century, could only agree on appointing a little-known Eurocrat to represent the EU in foreign policy and made no significant move towards taking charge of their joint defence.
Diplomats said the meagre result set to emerge from the EU's Amsterdam summit could reinforce the United States' pre-eminence in European security for years to come.

France and Germany, which had declared last year that Europe must have a single face and voice to run a credible foreign policy, settled in the end for making it a part-time job for the secretary-general of the EU's council of ministers.
That civil servant, who heads the policy-making council's Brussels secretariat, is currently a German named Juergen Trumpf, a former troubleshooter for Chancellor Helmut Kohl unknown to the public.

French officials who had insisted as late as Tuesday morning that the solution of making the council secretary-general into "Monsieur PESC" (Mr Common Foreign Policy), climbed down, saying the Dutch presidency's compromise proposal met France's needs.

They said Trumpf was nearing retirement and a higher-profile political figure might succeed him. But there was no sign that other countries, reluctant to see their own foreign ministers overshadowed, would necessarily agree to that.

The "secretary-general/high representative for common foreign and security policy" will assist the country holding the EU's rotating presidency in diplomacy and head a Brussels policy analysis and planning unit to improve crisis response.

Faced with dogged opposition from Britain and former neutral states to the EU becoming a defence organisation, the leaders were unable to agree to integrate the Western European Union (WEU) defence group into the Union.

Instead, they were set to decide the 10-nation WEU would remain an independent body, sub-contracted to carry out humanitarian, peacekeeping and crisis management missions for the Union "including peacemaking".
The idea of eventually merging the WEU into the Union was watered down to such an extent that even Britain's staunchly Atlanticist government was set to accept the wording.
The Dutch compromise said that closer relations between the two bodies "might in time lead to the integration of the WEU into the Union".
An aide to British Prime Minister Tony Blair told reporters: "He is not going to allow anything to go through which he believes could be interpreted as undermining NATO."
He quoted Blair as saying Britain was perfectly happy for closer cooperation with the WEU but Europe was not improved by integrating defence and foreign policy.

While Britain's main concern was not to weaken the American security guarantee for Europe, Ireland and three other neutral states which joined the EU in 1995 -- Sweden, Finland and Austria -- were wary about Europe becoming a military power.
Nordic countries were also concerned that getting the EU into defence could complicate the Baltic repubics' bids for membership by raising Russian objections.

Swedish chief negotiator Gunnar Lund said: "We object to the basic idea of enshrining into the treaty a clear-cut objective to integrate the EU and the WEU. We don't want to see that. We find that unacceptable.
"If this were done, it would unnecessarily complicate the (EU) enlargement process. It will accentuate divisions rather than unity within the EU in this particular area," he said.
